displaytitle: Ray System of Tycho, Waning Phase
creditline: Museum purchase, Fowler McCormick, Class of 1921, Fund
inscribed:
Printed on page, above image overall: PHOTOGRAPHIE LUNAIRE / RAYONNEMENT DE TYCHO — PHASE DÉCROISSANTE / PL XXXVII / Grand Equatorial Coudé /  Observatoire de Paris

Printed on page, below image overall: PAR M.M. LŒWY ET PUISEUX / 1900 Septembre 10 12h. 9 t.m. Paris / Agrandissement 7.69 fois / Diamètre Lunaire 1m.37 / Héliog. et Imp. L. Schutzenberger Paris

titles.title: Ray System of Tycho, Waning Phase

texts.textentryhtml: This image, portraying the same lunar topography seen in nearby photographs, was included in Loewy and Puiseux’s Atlas Photographieque de la lune (1896–1910). The twelve-volume Atlas although rightly considered "the ultimate achievement of nineteenth-century astronomical photography," is misleadingly titled: the authors did not attempt a systematic mapping of the moon, opting instead to present spectacular enlargements from the most dramatic photographs made at the Paris Observatory. Because perfect weather conditions were needed the entire atlas project was undertaken in installments over fourteen years.

The moon, in perpetual motion relative to ­observers on the earth, provided a literally moving target for photographic inventors who sought prestige, or patents, for their technological innovations. Astronomical partners Loewy and Puiseux are remembered for their Atlas photographique de la lune, published in twelve volumes of six enormous plates apiece, portraying features of the lunar surface. Atlas is a misleading title, for the sequence of plates fails to add up to a systematic geographic plan. Still, the detailed close-ups achieved by the team, printed as twelve- to eighteen-power photogravure enlargements, established a standard for resolution in lunar rendering that would not be surpassed until the advent of flight outside the stratosphere in the 1960s.

bibliography.boilertext: Observatoire de Paris, Atlas photographique de la lune (Paris:Imprimerie nationale, 1896-1910).
bibliography.citation: Observatoire de Paris, Atlas photographique de la lune (Paris:Imprimerie nationale, 1896-1910). , pp. 17–21
